questions.question: A 40-year-old man presents with swelling and mild pain in his left leg for several years. Physical examination revealed bulky, stiff skin with inguinal lymphadenopathy in the left lower limb (image). What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical findings?

A 42-year-old man presented to the hospital with swelling and thickening of both legs. A thick blood film revealed the following image. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the diagnosis of this condition? D. II Rapid detection test is used as an investigation of choice for this condition

options.A: Mass blood surveys with thick blood films are prepared between 10 AM to 2 PM
options.B: Drug provocation test has the highest specificity
options.C: Serological tests can differentiate between past and present infections

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Drug provocation test has the highest specificity Explanation: Diagnosis of filariasis 1. Thick blood film (Investigation of choice) Nocturnal microfilariae are seen in blood between 10 PM to 2 AM (Option A) Lymphatic filariasis Brugian/Malayan filariasis Large, smooth (graceful) curve with countable nuclei Small, kinked at an acute angle with a long head and uncountable nuclei, 2 nuclei in the tail tip 2. Rapid Detection Test Also called the filarial strip test Used for monitoring , mapping, and evaluation activities (Option D) 3. Membrane filter concentration method Most sensitive methods for detecting low-density microfilaraemia Require specialized equipment. 4. DEC provocation test: A single oral dose of 100mg DEC followed by blood smear after 1 hour Microfilariae can appear in the daytime. Highest specificity (Option B) 5. Serological tests

questions.question: A 42-year-old male presents with leg swelling and hydrocele on his left side. Blood tests reveal the presence of microfilariae of W. bancrofti. Which of the following statements regarding the management of the disease are false? Statements: Biannual mass drug administration with triple-drug therapy reduces transmission. Effective MDA coverage should be >90% for 5-6 years. A total dose of 72 mg/kg diethylcarbamazine (DEC) is the drug of choice for treating active filariasis. Integrated vector management includes anti-larval and anti-adult measures for preventing filariasis. Ivermectin 150-200 mcg as a combination treatment is effective in killing microfilariae
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) 1 and 2 Explanation: Management of Filariasis Treatment Triple Drug therapy Diethylcarbamazine ( DEC ): 6 mg/kg/day for 12 days + Albendazole stat (400 mg: > 2 years, 200mg: < 2 years ) + Ivermectin (150-200 mcg) Acute dermato-lymphangio adenitis (ADLA): Analgesics: Paracetamol Antibiotics: no anti filarial drug Uncomplicated: Amoxicillin, erythromycin Severe: IV Penicillin Prevention Annual Mass Drug Administration (MDA): Yearly triple drug therapy with DEC, albendazole and ivermectin Coverage: >65% for 5-6 years Lymphatic filariasis elimination strategy: microfilariae rate <1% Conduct a filarial survey in all age groups before starting MDA and a TAS (transmission assessment survey) among the 6-7 years age group after MDA Stop MDA if TAS < 2% followed by post-MDA surveillance with 2 more rounds of TAS DEC Medication Salts: 1- 4 gms of DEC is added per 1kg of salt in Maharashtra and Lakshadweep Islands Vector Control (Integrated vector management): Anti Larval: Larvicidal oil (pyrosene oil, fenthion, temephos) Anti-adult: DDT (6 monthly), lindane, malathion (quarterly) Aquatic plant removal: Water hyacinths, Pistia plants Monitoring Microfilaria rate: Most sensitive indicator Persons with microfilaria /20 mm3 of blood / total population × 100 Indicates prevalence of infection . Filarial endemicity rate: Persons with microfilaria + clinical diagnosis / Total population × 100 Indicates prevalence of disease. Microfilaria density: Percentage of microfilaria per unit volume of blood Indicates intensity of infection (endemicity potential). Average infestation rate: Average microfilaria per positive slide Microfilaria prevalence in the area Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 317-321

questions.question: A 30-year-old male farmer presents with worsening fever and weight loss for the last 2 months. Physical examination demonstrated significant hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory tests show pancytopenia and a positive rk39 test. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Liposomal amphotericin B Explanation: Treatment with liposomal amphotericin B is recommended for visceral leishmaniasis, which is most likely the cause of this patient's clinical symptoms (fever, hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia), and a positive rk39 antigen. Kala-azar/ Black sickness/Dum-dum fever/Sandfly disease/ Visceral Leishmaniasis Organism Protozoan Epidemiology Endemic in Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, West Bengal Types Visceral (Kala-Azar) : L. donovani Cutaneous : L. tropica (oriental sore/ delhi boil/ Aleppo button) Mucocutaneous : L. braziliensis (espundia) Post-kala-azar dermal ( PKLD ): Immune response Reservoir Humans (non-zoonotic) Vector Sandfly (Phlebotomus argentipes): has hairy wings. Environmental Peak outbreak: November to April Mechanism of transmission Bite of sandfly Blood transfusion (rare) Incubation period 10 days to 2 years. (1-4 months average) Clinical features Visceral: Fever, Weight loss, Hepatosplenomegaly, Anemia. Cutaneous: Painful skin ulcers Mucocutaneous: Rapid mucosal destruction of nose and oropharynx PKDL: Skin nodules filled with micro-organisms Diagnosis Rapid diagnostic kits: rk39-dipstick test . Used for field surveys. Biopsy (Gold standard) : Leishmania Donovan bodies Sandfly control measures DDT: 1-2gm/m 2 . BHC (benzene hexachloride) Treatment DOC: Single dose Liposomal amphotericin-B (LAMB)10 mg/kg Alternatives: Miltefosine + Paramomycin (Options B and D) Pentamidine (Option C) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 351-356

questions.question: A 45-year-old male who works in flooded rice fields presents with a 5-day history of high fever, headache, and yellowing of the eyes. Physical examination demonstrated conjunctival redness and calf tenderness. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Leptospirosis Explanation: Leptospirosis is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with high fever, severe headache, muscle pain, calf tenderness, conjunctival suffusion, jaundice, and a history of exposure to flooded rice paddies. Leptospirosis Agent Leptospira interrogans (zoonotic bacteria) Reservoir Rodents (Ratus norvegicus, Mus musculus) and domestic animals Source Direct contact or contamination with excreta, urine of infected animals. At risk individuals Males 20-45 years (most common) Urine-contaminated mud(Soil) or water Sports: rafting, fishing and swimming Rice field workers, sewer workers, animal handlers Mode of transmission Direct contact: Urine through skin abrasion Indirect contact: Contact of broken skin with soil, water, vegetation Droplet infection: Inhalation while milking cows. Incubation 4-20 days Diagnosis Clinical features Darkfield examination: Thin and motile spirochete . IgM ELISA : High sensitivity Labs: Elevated liver enzymes, increased bilirubin , thrombocytopenia Dengue (Option A) typically presents with high fever, severe headache, retro-orbital pain, rash, and bleeding tendencies with laboratory tests showing thrombocytopenia. Malaria (Option B) presents with periodic fevers, jaundice, headache, and muscle pain. A blood smear shows intraerythrocytic plasmodium parasites. Hepatitis A (Option D) causes jaundice and elevated liver enzymes but it is transmitted through contaminated food and water and is less associated with working in flooded paddies.

questions.question: Which of the following antibiotics is not recommended for the treatment of leptospirosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Ciprofloxacin Explanation: Ciprofloxacin, a bacterial DNA gyrase inhibitor, is ineffective for treating leptospirosis. Management of Leptospirosis: Treatment DOC: Penicillin 6 million units daily. (OPTION B) Alternate drugs: Doxycycline (OPTION A) Amoxicillin (OPTION C) Ampicillin Ceftriaxone Prevention Avoid contaminated water and use protective clothing Livestock vaccination, proper waste disposal Rodent control measures: Zinc phosphide Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition Pg: 338-339

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the epidemiological features of Japanese Encephalitis is incorrect?

options.A: The virus belongs to the Flaviviridae family
options.B: Humans are the primary reservoir hosts for the Japanese Encephalitis irus
options.C: Primary vectors for Japanese Encephalitis are Culex mosquitoes.

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Humans are the primary reservoir hosts for the Japanese Encephalitis virus reservoirs are pigs and wading birds and humans are incidental hosts, meaning they can be infected but do not play a significant role in the transmission cycle because they do not produce enough virus in their blood to infect mosquitoes. Epidemiological features of Japanese encephalitis Agent Japanese Encephalitis Virus (JEV), Group B Arbovirus Virus Family: Flaviviridae (Option A) Transmission Vector Culex mosquitoes (Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui) (Option C) Hosts Pigs (Amplifier Host) Ardeid Birds: Pond herons, Ducks, Poultry (Maintenance Host) Man: (Accidental or dead-end host) Do not develop high enough viremia to infect mosquitoes. Primarily children (below 15 years), but all ages susceptible No man-to-man transmission. Horses: Only animals that can manifest symptoms (Option D). Environmental Factors Geographic Distribution: Southeast Asia, East Asia, and the Western Pacific regions. India Endemic: To 21 states but mainly includes Jharkhand, Bihar, West Bengal, Uttar Pradesh, Assam and Haryana Seasonal Distribution: Monsoon and post-monsoon period (varies by region)

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy from rural Uttar Pradesh presents with high fever, severe headache, vomiting, altered mental status, neck stiffness, and positive Brudzinski's sign. He is unvaccinated and lives near rice fields and pig farms during the monsoon season. What is the most likely diagnosis and the investigation of choice for confirmation?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Japanese Encephalitis; IgM ELISA Explanation : Given the patient's symptoms and lack of vaccination, Japanese encephalitis is the most likely diagnosis. The investigation of choice for confirming JE is the IgM ELISA test for the JE virus, which detects specific antibodies in the patient's serum or cerebrospinal fluid. Japanese encephalitis Incubation Period 5-15 days Symptoms Mild: fever and headache Severe: high fever, headache, neck stiffness, seizures, coma Case Fatality Rate 20-30% in severe cases Long-term Sequelae Neurological and psychiatric sequelae in 30-50% of survivors Diagnosis Serological tests (IgM ELISA), PCR Bacterial meningitis (Option A) can cause similar symptoms (fever, headache, neck stiffness), and the specific epidemiological context (rice fields and pig farms) and season (monsoon) strongly suggest Japanese encephalitis. Blood cultures are also less specific for CNS infections than CSF analysis and PCR. HSV encephalitis (Option B) can present with similar symptoms, but given the epidemiological context (rice fields and pig farms during monsoon season), it is less likely. The symptoms are more indicative of Japanese encephalitis. Dengue fever (Option D) commonly presents with high fever, severe headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, and sometimes a rash. However, it does not typically cause neck stiffness or altered mental status indicative of central nervous system involvement. Additionally, while dengue is prevalent in monsoon seasons, the specific history of living near rice fields and pig farms is more indicative of Japanese encephalitis. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine (27th edition) Page.332 IAPSM textbook of Community medicine (2nd edition) Page.400,401

questions.question: All of the following are true about the Live-attenuated JE vaccine except?

options.A: Included in the national immunisation schedule.
options.C: Vaccination schedules include a primary series followed by a booster dose.
options.D: It can be administered to children as young as 6 months old.

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Can be administered to children as young as 6 months old. Explanation: The JE vaccine is recommended for children and is administered starting at 9 months of age or older. Japanese encephalitis vaccines Types Inactivated vaccine (Nakayama) Live attenuated vaccine (SA-14-14-2), the mostly preferred Diluent: Phosphate buffer since the J I vaccine is in powdered form. The vaccine used to be included in the National Immunization Schedule(NIS) targeting high-risk regions. 3. The killed vaccine in India is JENVAC - Kolar strain which is given IM injection. It has been added to the National Immunization Schedule (NIS). Dosage Administered 2 Doses 1st: 9 months 2nd: 6 to 24 months Min Gap between 2 doses → 3 months, 0.5 ml (left arm) Route: Subcutaneous In case of non-immunized children : Can be given to children < 15 years of age Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page.332,333 IAPSM textbook of Community medicine, 2nd edition, Page.401,402 https://iapindia.org/pdf/vaccine-information/JAPANESE-ENCEPHALITIS-VACCINES.pdf

questions.question: A 30-year-old non-immunized traveler returns from a trip to a tropical region and presents with a high fever, chills, severe headache, muscle pain, nausea, vomiting, and jaundice. Which of the following parameters is unsuitable for transmitting the suspected disease?

options.D: Presence of monkeys in the area

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Temperature of climate ranging 18-24°C Explanation: Yellow fever transmission is less likely in cooler temperatures. Aedes mosquitoes thrive in warmer climates, typically between 24-36°C. Therefore, a climate with temperatures ranging from 18-24°C is unsuitable for transmitting yellow fever. Yellow fever Agent and Vector Flavivirus transmitted primarily by mosquitoes Aedes Mosquito (in urban settings) Haemagogus (in jungle or forested areas) Hosts Primarily monkeys (Reservoir hosts) Humans are (Incidental hosts) and can develop severe disease. Environmental Features Found in tropical and subtropical areas of Africa and South America, where mosquito vectors are prevalent. Transmission occurs primarily in forested or jungle areas. Typical Conditions: Temperature: 24-36’C Humidity: >60% Clinical Presentation Initial symptoms (acute phase, 3-6 days post-infection): fever, chills, headache, backache, muscle aches, loss of appetite. Severe cases (toxic phase): jaundice, bleeding, organ dysfunction (liver, kidney). Diagnosis Based on clinical signs Travel history to endemic areas Confirmed by detection of YFV RNA or specific antibodies (IgM and IgG) in blood samples. High humidity levels (>60%) (Option A) create favourable conditions for the breeding and activity of mosquitoes, including the Aedes species responsible for yellow fever transmission. Aedes mosquitoes (Option C) , transmit the virus through their bites, making this parameter crucial for the transmission of yellow fever. Monkeys (Option D) serve as natural hosts for the yellow fever virus in sylvatic (jungle) cycles. Their presence indicates the potential for the virus to circulate in the environment, with mosquitoes acting as vectors to transmit it to humans. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine (27th edition) Page. 328 IAPSM textbook of Community medicine (2nd edition) Page. 392,393

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the yellow fever vaccine are correct? Intradermal administration The recommended age for administration is 7 months or older. A booster dose is required every 10 years for continued immunity. The vaccine contains a live-attenuated virus. A yellow card is issued for travel.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) 4 and 5 Explanation: Yellow fever vaccine Types Live-attenuated vaccine (17D strain) Diluent: lyophilized (freeze-dried) powder with saline solution. Administration Route: Subcutaneous Dose: A single dose, 0.5 mL Site: Deltoid muscle Age for Administration: Recommended for individuals completed 9 months. 6 months (outbreak situations) Efficacy Onset of Immunity: Within 30 days Duration of Immunity: A single dose provides lifelong immunity. Indications Individuals traveling to endemic areas, including parts of Africa and South America. Contraindications Allergies to any component of the vaccine, especially egg proteins. Immunocompromised Infants under 6 months Pregnancy: Generally avoided unless the risk is high. Additional Proof of vaccination (Yellow card) is required for entry into certain countries. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine (27th edition) Page. 328,329 IAPSM textbook of Community medicine (2nd edition) Page. 393,394

questions.question: Which of the following are the intermediate hosts of dracunculiasis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Cyclops Explanation: Cyclops are intermediate hosts of dracunculiasis (guinea-worm disease). Cyclops: Synonym Water flea Habitat Freshwater Morphology Not more than 1 mm in length Pear-shaped semi-transparent body Forked tail 2 pairs of antennae Health Importance Intermediate host of dracunculiasis [guinea-worm disease] Transmit fish tapeworms [Diphyllobothrium latum] Control measures Straining and boiling water Chemicals like chlorine, lime, and abate Using barbel-gambusia fishes Avoiding step wells Sandfly (Option A) transmits leishmaniasis which is a protozoan disease most commonly seen in Europe, Asia, Africa, and Latin America. Hard ticks (Option B) are vectors of many parasitic and bacterial infections like tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularaemia, and tick paralysis. Soft ticks (Option C) transmit Q-fever, relapsing fever, and KFD. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 908 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK531456/

questions.question: A 35-year-old farmer from a tropical region presented with chronic fatigue and pallor. There is a history of barefoot farming practices and frequent contact with soil contaminated by human feces. Laboratory tests revealed severe iron deficiency anemia. What number of eggs per gram of stool of this farmer makes this disease a major public health problem?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) >300 Explanation: The farmer's symptoms of chronic fatigue, pallor, and severe iron deficiency anaemia, combined with the history of barefoot farming in contaminated soil, suggest hookworm infection. A Chandler’s index of >300 indicates it is a major public health problem. Chandler’s index is an indicator for assessing the severity of ancylostomiasis based on the average number of hookworm eggs per gram of stools. Average no. of eggs/g of stools Significance <200 Not of much importance 200-250 Indicates potential danger 250-300 Indicates minor public health problem >300 Major public health problem Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pages 285-286. AH Suryakantha Community Medicine with Recent Advances (2014), 3rd edition, page 413.
